qas.question: Under what type of tradition did Sanskrit begin?
After what language evolved was writing introduced?
What feature of written text influenced the use of scripts?
What does Sanskrit not have of its own?
Which writing systems have been used to write Sanskrit?
What originated in a progressive society?
What written tradition was maintained in early literature?
What influenced the original scripts of the scribes?
What was used in very few writing systems in South Asia?

context: Sanskrit originated in an oral society, and the <a0_0>oral tradition<a0_0/> was maintained through the development of early classical <b6_0>Sanskrit<b6_0/> literature. Writing was not introduced to India until after <b7_0>Sanskrit<b7_0/> had evolved into the <a1_0><b5_0><b8_0>Prakrits<b8_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>; when it was written, the choice of writing system was influenced by the <a2_0>regional scripts<a2_0/> of the scribes. Therefore, Sanskrit has no <a3_0>native script<a3_0/> of its own. As such, virtually <a4_0>all<a4_0/> the major writing systems of South Asia have been used for the production of <b9_0>Sanskrit manuscripts<b9_0/>.
